comment: Consider benefit to researcher for now, keeping wider impact in view, in expectation that will flow through later. Try to capture both aspects in “So that...” column.
reqs.require: to search => find (parts of) existing workflows that do something similar to what is required for my experiment
reason: I can get ideas for my own work
I can compare with my work ('related work')
I can reuse in my own analysis
I can understand a method
I can reuse the results

reqs.require: to reference the experiment that provides the input to the workflow (including paper reference, if any)
reason: I can acknowledge data providers

reqs.require: to record my initial experimental hypothesis
reason: I can link the experimental design to its purpose (onset)
others can find my work based on its purpose

comment: “conceptual workflow” is a concrete workflow that makes reference to unimplemented or unspecified elements; e.g. Taverna w/f with reference to dummy elements (e.g. can fake with beanshell)
reqs.require: to assemble conceptual workflow
reason: I can discuss my plans with supervisors/peers
I can start searching for components

reqs.require: to adapt an existing workflow to my needs
reason: I can avoid having to learn (or remember?) everything about creating workflows (note: newbie scenario)

reqs.require: to search for workflows by keywords about purpose, context, and outcome of experiment
reason: I can find workflows relevant to my experiment

reqs.require: to run an existing workflow with different data
reason: I can understand the workflow
I can get more biological results efficiently

reqs.require: to compare results of workflow run with other results
reason: I can understand the results in biological terms, compare with competition

reqs.require: to create new workflows with my own scripts
reason: I can ''get on with it' without trying to understand other people's work

reqs.require: to run workflow scripts provided by colleagues
reason: I can perform experiments for which the methods are familiar to my direct colleagues
I can shorten the start-up phase and lower the risk of unexpected bottlenecks

reqs.require: to record notes relating to experiment (design and run-time log)
reason: I can document my considerations during design and execution, linked to design, run, and input/output data.

reqs.require: to record revised experimental hypothesis
reason: I can link experimental design and execution to the purpose of the experiment

reqs.require: to search for 'follow-up' workflows
reason: I can create a new workflow or revise my own to test the improved hypothesis or new questions derived from the previous results

comment: Expand benefit?
reqs.require: to record reasons for workflow revision
reason: Link new workflow to previous workflow

reqs.require: to link test results and interpretation to initial hypothesis
reason: retrieve past information about and interrelations between hypotheses

reqs.require: to see the rationale for existing workflows
reason: I can better understand an existing workflow, and find help to interpret results of my own workflows

comment: (needs clarification/example)
reqs.require: to annotate data with information from global databases
reason: I can relate results to work from other experiments

reqs.require: to record biological interpretation of results, linked to experiment and data used
reason: I can organize my information for me, my colleagues and later publication
other researchers interested in investigating similar biological phenomena can find and re-use my work.

comment: In this scenario researcher Kristina will take the result of a genome wide association study experiment (GWAS) and a metabolomics experiment (SNPs related to metabolites) and map it to biological concepts using text mining technology. The GWAS and metabolomics experiments were done by others than Kristina. She makes a note of the origin ...
reqs.require: to record the origin of experimental data used for analysis

comment: … (including the still confidential research proposal for the study)
reqs.require: to record information that must be kept confidential

comment: Kristina is new to workflows, so she wishes to start with an existing workflow. When she started on the project she was introduced to people that perform related work. She knows that one of her colleagues is making a workflow for the mapping of SNPs to genes, and then onto pathways. She also knows that another colleague has created an abstract workflow for parts of the text mining technology that she wants to use.
reqs.require: to adapt existing workflows for a new study
reason: I can benefit from the knowledge and previous work of colleagues

comment: She wishes to understand these workflows and asks her colleagues to explain their functionality to her.
reqs.require: to understand existing workflows
reason: I can benefit from the knowledge and previous work of colleagues

comment: She decides that she would like to build a workflow that would integrate the text mining technology with the one already implemented for the SNP-gene-pathway pipeline.
reqs.require: to build a new workflow from more than one existing workflow
reason: I can benefit from the knowledge and previous work of colleagues

comment: However, the abstract workflow for the text mining technology will probably take a long time to implement since the underlying web services that are needed do not actually exist yet. She is dependent on another colleague to implement these for her. At this point she decides to make an abstract workflow of her own, that she will use as a reference when explaining her research and analysis steps.
reqs.require: to record an abstract (not-yet-implemented) workflow
reason: I can explain my needs to colleagues who will implement processes I shall need

comment: This tool is however in need of an update, which she will perform. In the mean time, the ordering customer, which is the scientist that provided the original data, is getting impatient and wants results. She therefore decides to run the analysis with the version of the tool that is available. She uses the output from the already available SNP-gene-pathway workflow to map SNPs to genes, ending up with a list of genes for a metabolite. This lists she feeds into the tool.
reqs.require: to run a workflow with an alternative processing tool ...OR... to partially execute a workflow, with unavailable sections replaced by manual processes ?????
reason: I can make progress in my research while waiting for processing tools or other workflows to be implemented

comment: Ultimately, the workflow (or at this point the tool that is actually available) suggests for example that one gene in the set of genes associated with a specific metabolite actually is associated with the metabolite via the Gluconeogenesis biological process. It is one of the two main mechanisms humans and many other animals use to keep blood glucose levels from dropping too low (hypoglycemia), information he finds on the Internet. She makes a note of that and goes back to the tool to see if Gluconeogenesis is a process that is known to be associated with MetS.
reqs.require: to record information that is discovered from other external sources
reason: I can keep track of reasons for decisions made in the conduct of my studies

comment: She will perform the same type of analysis for the different genes associated with the metabolite, and also for the list of genes as a whole. These analyses will lead to a number of candidate biological processes hypothesized to explain the gene-metabolite associations.
reqs.require: to repeatedly re-run a workflow with different input parameters and/or data
reason: I can look for potential links between my results and other known biological mechanisms

comment: This is now her interpretation of her experiment that she wishes to link to her experiment and the processed data.
reqs.require: to record an interpretation of results obtained, linked to the experimental record and input data used

comment: Kristina notes that in a next cycle she will want to perform another workflow that compares her results using text mining with the results from the already available SNP-gene-pathway workflow.
reqs.require: to record notes for future work

comment: In this case she will link the result from this workflow to the previous experiment and in particular to the initial hypothesis. At some point, she wishes to be able to retrieve this past information and the interrelationships among his hypotheses.
reqs.require: link workflow results to previous results, procedures and hypotheses
reason: I can subsequently retrieve information about the relationship between hypotheses and results obtained

comment: Assuming her finding and new hypotheses are valuable and new, she will publish her results. The publication has cleaned information, sufficient for evaluating her hypothesis and rerunning the one workflow and the one dataset that lead to this result.
reqs.require: Extract information from a working RO for publication
reason: I can easily use my working notes as a basis for creating the distilled information needed for publication.

comment: submission is the best moment to help users follow standards (for useful preservation; i.e. enhance usage later on)
reqs.require: the repository submission process to help me arrange data according to accepted standards
reason: subsequent use of preserved information is or can be enhanced

comment: For comparison: when genetic variants are submitted to an archive and as part of a paper, we can suggest the proper encoding for genetic variants (this is non-trivial). This semantically links the papers mentioning the variant to one another and to any database using the same encoding for variants.
reqs.require: archive submission of genetic variants that are part of a paper to suggest a standard encoding of genetic variants
reason: the papers mentioning a genetic variant can be semantically linked to each other, and to database records

comment: For workflows I imagine that submission would be the moment of matching a workflow with the RO model. When mismatches occur, we can ask the user to disambiguate or add missing information.
Assumes some kind of RO model specific to the experimental circumstance?

This may come with some 'pain', because it may require a mapping for existing resources.
The process is facilitated by publishing the RO model.
reqs.require: archive submission of a workflow to be matched with the [prevailing? experiment?] Research Object model, requiring a user to correct mismatches and resolve ambiguities
reason: (common format elements facilitate subsequent processing?)

comment: Example for living ROs … I would like to see these in the context of helping users keep a proper notebook. In my vision, the notebook creates the archive (or prepares for archival). Every submission of an artefact+notes comes with storing provenance information, that a user can later use to look up information before publishing. So for instance, when a workflow produces an output that we wish to keep, we don't have to worry about its timestamp and metadata remaining linked to it.
In summary: I expect that the process of submission for living ROs would look like an aid in keeping track of your experiment for users
reqs.require: every submission of an artefeact and/or notes to a “Living RO” to capture provenance (who, when, etc.) about that submission
reason: Information is properly prepared and annotated for subsequent archival.
Provenance information can be used to locate and keep track of saved information prior to publication
Useful workflow outputs acquire a provenance history that support the result.

comment: Example for publication ROs … I expect that the process of publishing is a matter of copying, pruning, and editing a living RO.
reqs.require: publication ROs to be created from living ROs by a process of copying, pruning and editing
reason: (the publication RO is clearly and explicitly linked to day-to-day lab work??)

comment: This may be facilitated by matching to the potential difference that may exist in the RO model instance of the 'living' and 'published' ROs. It can guide in what to remove (e.g. intermediate datasets),
reqs.require: assistance in generating a publication RO from a living RO by matching living and publication RO models
reason: the process of preparing a publication object is facilitated

comment: and it may be more strict about which information should minimally be provided, similar to the strict requirements for publications
reqs.require: enforcement of minimum requirements for a publication RO to be enforced.
reason: (adherence to community standards for publication is maintained)

comment:
(In practice this is the time where as user you feel sorry that you didn't provide this information to the living object earlier.)
Taking E's case as an example. She is producing a workflow from the compendium of R scripts that she used to explore the effect of so-called CpG islands (specific sequences often found in front of genes; their locations taken from an on line data source) on the change of gene expression in brain regions affected by Huntington's Disease. She has done several analyses for different kind of statistical plots (we assume these are in the living RO4), and now wishes to fix the workflow (in Taverna) and select the results for publication.
reqs.require: RO submission to suggest/encourage provision of information that will later be needed for publication
reason: subsequent publication of the results of an investigation is made easier

comment: Note: within our department we are developing a tool for generating interfaces for command line tools; the underlying model is in RDF. For each tool (e.g. Galaxy tools) a mapping is made in a template language. This is a bottleneck, but the RDF part facilitates interoperability.
reqs.require: tools to use standard formats for representing underlying experimental data and models
reason: interoperability between systems and users is facilitated

comment: It may be worthwhile to align with Study Capture frameworks here. I suggest to try to use the same semantic models under the hood as much as possible.
reqs.require: captured information to conform to standard semantic “study framework” models

comment: It may help if living RO's seem entirely personal, until a user is ready to share. Eleni is a typical PhD student/scientist; feeling uncomfortable sharing until she is entirely confident about the result. NB, following the wet-lab analogy this is not acceptable; notebooks are in principle property of the department and open to it (in practice this is not nastily adhered to though)
reqs.require: working ROs to be presented and managed as a personal workspace
reason: I can work privately with my notes and intermediate results until I am confident of having some result worth sharing
